title: What is the objective logic behind ancient institutions and laws that modern people can no longer understand?
first_phrase: This text discusses the existence of objective and rational laws that govern human life, which are often discredited or misunderstood by modern society. The author argues that while individuals may have control over their internal behavior and decisions, external circumstances and collective actions also determine one's fate. The concept of shared destinies and the impact of collective events, such as epidemics or wars, are explored. The final 200 words stress the importance of accepting and recognizing these shared destinies, rather than protesting them. The author emphasizes the need for individuals to understand their place within larger systems and to acknowledge the influence of external forces on their lives.
content: Ma già come mente, poi come vita, poi come corpo, l'uomo cessa di appartenere soltanto a sé stesso, e partecipa del destino di enti collettivi: inoltre la sua stessa azione e disposizione crea nuove e piú speciali comunanze, che complicano con altri fili il nodo. Protestare per il fatto che si possa rispondere per altri, o subire l'azio- ne di altri (anche senza saperlo), significa disconoscere que- sti destini comuni, propri a tutto ciò che nell'uomo non è iI puro « io ». Il fatto ingiusto del « contagio » di reazioni e di comuni casi di vita, oltre che in piccolo, nelle forme su cui « Ermo » ha portato l'attenzione, si ritrova in grande: in cataclismi, in epidemie, in guerre. Non si protesta, di so- lito, perché non si presenta il sospetto, che questi avveni- menti siano scariche di rimbalzo determinate attraverso la legge degli enti da cause, che vanno a colpire tutta una comunità, senza differenza.
last_phrase: In conclusion, as humans, we are not solely responsible for our own destinies once we become part of collective entities through our minds, lives, and bodies. Our actions and dispositions can create new and complex communities that further complicate the ties that bind us together. Therefore, protesting against the contagion of reactions and common life events is to deny our shared destinies with others. We must accept that our fates are intertwined with those around us, and that what one gains, another must lose. This is the law of action and reaction, which applies not only to individuals but also to entire communities, and it is a reality that we cannot escape.
